pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:0.3.eng: The chapter on offenses entailing confession

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:0.5.eng: 8. The training rule on telling truthfully

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.1.1.pli: Tena samayena buddho bhagavā vesāliyaṃ viharati mahāvane kūṭāgārasālāyaṃ.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.1.1.eng: At one time when the Buddha was staying in the hall with the peaked roof in the Great Wood near Vesālī,

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.1.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena sambahulā sandiṭṭhā sambhattā bhikkhū vaggumudāya nadiyā tīre vassaṃ upagacchiṃsu.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.1.2.eng: a number of monks who were friends had entered the rainy-season residence on the banks of the river Vaggumudā.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.1.3.pli: Tena kho pana samayena vajjī dubbhikkhā hoti—dvīhitikā setaṭṭhikā salākāvuttā, na sukarā uñchena paggahena yāpetuṃ.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.1.3.eng: At that time Vajjī was short of food and afflicted with hunger, with crops affected by whiteheads and turned to straw. It was not easy to get by on almsfood.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.1.3.comm: “Whiteheads” renders setaṭṭ(h)ikā, literally, “white bones”. Sp 4.403: Setaṭṭhikā nāma rogajātīti eko pāṇako nāḷimajjhagataṁ kaṇḍaṁ vijjhati, yena viddhattā nikkhantampi sālisīsaṁ khīraṁ gahetuṁ na sakkoti, “The disease called setaṭṭhikā means: an insect penetrates the stem, goes to the middle of the stalk, from the penetration of which the rice grains are not able to get sap.” This seems to be a description of so-called “whiteheads”, pale panicles without rice grains, caused by stem borers.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.1.4.pli: Atha kho tesaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ etadahosi—“etarahi kho vajjī dubbhikkhā—dvīhitikā setaṭṭhikā salākāvuttā, na sukarā uñchena paggahena yāpetuṃ. Kena nu kho mayaṃ upāyena samaggā sammodamānā avivadamānā phāsukaṃ vassaṃ vaseyyāma, na ca piṇḍakena kilameyyāmā”ti?
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.1.4.eng: The monks considered the difficult circumstances, and they thought, “How can we live together in peace and harmony, have a comfortable rains, and get almsfood without trouble?”

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.1.5.pli: Ekacce evamāhaṃsu—“handa mayaṃ, āvuso, gihīnaṃ kammantaṃ adhiṭṭhema. Evaṃ te amhākaṃ dātuṃ maññissanti.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.1.5.eng: Some said, “We could work for the householders, and they’ll support us in return.”

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.1.6.pli: Evaṃ mayaṃ samaggā sammodamānā avivadamānā phāsukaṃ vassaṃ vasissāma, na ca piṇḍakena kilamissāmā”ti.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.1.7.pli: Ekacce evamāhaṃsu—“alaṃ, āvuso, kiṃ gihīnaṃ kammantaṃ adhiṭṭhitena?
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.1.7.eng: Others said, “There’s no need to work for the householders.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.1.8.pli: Handa mayaṃ, āvuso, gihīnaṃ dūteyyaṃ harāma. Evaṃ te amhākaṃ dātuṃ maññissanti.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.1.8.eng: Let’s instead take messages for them, and they’ll support us in return.”

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.1.9.pli: Evaṃ mayaṃ samaggā sammodamānā avivadamānā phāsukaṃ vassaṃ vasissāma, na ca piṇḍakena kilamissāmā”ti.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.1.10.pli: Ekacce evamāhaṃsu—“alaṃ, āvuso; kiṃ gihīnaṃ kammantaṃ adhiṭṭhitena. Kiṃ gihīnaṃ dūteyyaṃ haṭena.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.1.10.eng: Still others said, “There’s no need to do work or take messages for them.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.1.11.pli: Handa mayaṃ, āvuso, gihīnaṃ aññamaññassa uttarimanussadhammassa vaṇṇaṃ bhāsissāma—
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.1.11.eng: Let’s instead talk up one another’s superhuman qualities to the householders:

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.1.12.pli: ‘asuko bhikkhu paṭhamassa jhānassa lābhī, asuko bhikkhu dutiyassa jhānassa lābhī, asuko bhikkhu tatiyassa jhānassa lābhī, asuko bhikkhu catutthassa jhānassa lābhī, asuko bhikkhu sotāpanno, asuko bhikkhu sakadāgāmī, asuko bhikkhu anāgāmī, asuko bhikkhu arahā, asuko bhikkhu tevijjo, asuko bhikkhu chaḷabhiñño’ti.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.1.12.eng: ‘That monk has the first absorption, that monk the second absorption, that monk the third, that monk the fourth; that monk is a stream-enterer, that monk a once-returner, that a non-returner, that a perfected one; that monk has the three true insights, and that the six direct knowledges.’

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.1.14.pli: Evaṃ mayaṃ samaggā sammodamānā avivadamānā phāsukaṃ vassaṃ vasissāma, na ca piṇḍakena kilamissāmā”ti.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.1.14.eng: In this way we’ll have a comfortable rains, live together in peace and harmony, and get almsfood without trouble.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.1.15.pli: “Eso yeva kho, āvuso, seyyo, yo amhākaṃ gihīnaṃ aññamaññassa uttarimanussadhammassa vaṇṇo bhāsito”ti.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.1.15.eng: This is the way to go.”

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.1.16.pli: Atha kho te bhikkhū gihīnaṃ aññamaññassa uttarimanussadhammassa vaṇṇaṃ bhāsiṃsu—
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.1.16.eng: Then those monks did just that.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.1.17.pli: “asuko bhikkhu paṭhamassa jhānassa lābhī …pe… asuko bhikkhu chaḷabhiñño”ti.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.1.18.pli: Atha kho te manussā—“lābhā vata no, suladdhaṃ vata no, yesaṃ no evarūpā bhikkhū vassaṃ upagatā, na vata no ito pubbe evarūpā bhikkhū vassaṃ upagatā, yathayime bhikkhū sīlavanto kalyāṇadhammā”ti.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.1.18.eng: And the people there thought, “We’re so fortunate that such monks have come to us for the rainy-season residence. Such virtuous and good monks have never before entered the rains residence with us.”

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.1.19.pli: Te na tādisāni bhojanāni attanā bhuñjanti, mātāpitūnaṃ denti puttadārassa denti dāsakammakaraporisassa denti mittāmaccānaṃ denti ñātisālohitānaṃ denti yādisāni bhikkhūnaṃ denti.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.1.19.eng: And they gave such food and drink to those monks that they did not even eat and drink themselves, or give to their parents, to their wives and children, to their slaves, servants, and workers, to their friends and companions, or to their relatives.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.1.20.pli: Na tādisāni khādanīyāni sāyanīyāni pānāni attanā khādanti sāyanti pivanti mātāpitūnaṃ denti puttadārassa denti dāsakammakaraporisassa denti mittāmaccānaṃ denti ñātisālohitānaṃ denti, yādisāni bhikkhūnaṃ denti.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.1.21.pli: Atha kho te bhikkhū vaṇṇavā ahesuṃ pīṇindriyā pasannamukhavaṇṇā vippasannachavivaṇṇā.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.1.21.eng: Soon those monks had a good color, bright faces, clear skin, and sharp senses.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.2.1.pli: Āciṇṇaṃ kho panetaṃ vassaṃvuṭṭhānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ bhagavantaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamituṃ.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.2.1.eng: Now it was the custom for monks who had completed the rainy-season residence to go and visit the Buddha.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.2.2.pli: Atha kho te bhikkhū vassaṃvuṭṭhā temāsaccayena senāsanaṃ saṃsāmetvā pattacīvaramādāya yena vesālī tena pakkamiṃsu.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.2.2.eng: And so, when the three months were over and they had completed the rains residence, those monks put their dwellings in order, took their bowls and robes, and set out for Vesālī.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.2.3.pli: Anupubbena yena vesālī mahāvanaṃ kūṭāgārasālā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.2.3.eng: When they eventually arrived, they went to the hall with the peaked roof in the Great Wood.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.2.4.eng: There they approached the Buddha, bowed, and sat down.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.2.5.pli: Tena kho pana samayena disāsu vassaṃvuṭṭhā bhikkhū kisā honti lūkhā dubbaṇṇā uppaṇḍuppaṇḍukajātā dhamanisanthatagattā.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.2.5.eng: At that time the monks who had completed the rains residence in that region were thin, haggard and pale, with veins protruding all over their bodies.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.2.6.pli: Vaggumudātīriyā pana bhikkhū vaṇṇavā honti pīṇindriyā pasannamukhavaṇṇā vippasannachavivaṇṇā.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.2.6.eng: Yet the monks from the banks of the Vaggumudā had a good color, bright faces, clear skin, and  sharp senses.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.2.7.pli: Āciṇṇaṃ kho panetaṃ buddhānaṃ bhagavantānaṃ āgantukehi bhikkhūhi saddhiṃ paṭisammodituṃ.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.2.7.eng: Since it is the custom for Buddhas to greet newly-arrived monks,

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.2.8.pli: Atha kho bhagavā vaggumudātīriye bhikkhū etadavoca—

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.2.9.eng: “I hope you’re keeping well, monks, I hope you’re getting by?

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.2.10.pli: kacci samaggā sammodamānā avivadamānā phāsukaṃ vassaṃ vasittha, na ca piṇḍakena kilamitthā”ti?
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.2.10.eng: I hope you had a comfortable and harmonious rains, and got almsfood without trouble?”

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.2.11.eng: “We’re keeping well, sir, we’re getting by.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.2.12.pli: Samaggā ca mayaṃ, bhante, sammodamānā avivadamānā phāsukaṃ vassaṃ vasimhā, na ca piṇḍakena kilamimhā”ti.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.2.12.eng: We had a comfortable and harmonious rains, and got almsfood without trouble.”

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.2.13.pli: Jānantāpi tathāgatā pucchanti, jānantāpi na pucchanti.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.2.13.eng: When Buddhas know what is going on, sometimes they ask and sometimes not.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.2.14.pli: Kālaṃ viditvā pucchanti, kālaṃ viditvā na pucchanti.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.2.14.eng: They know the right time to ask and when not to ask.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.2.15.eng: Buddhas ask when it is beneficial, otherwise not,

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.2.16.eng: for Buddhas are incapable of doing what is unbeneficial.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.2.16.comm: “Incapable of doing” renders setughāta, literally, “destroyed the bridge”. Sp 1.16: Setu vuccati maggo, maggeneva tādisassa vacanassa ghāto, samucchedoti vuttaṁ hoti, “The path is called the bridge. What is said is that there is the destruction and cutting off of such speech by the path.” The commentary seems to take setu, “bridge”, as a reference to the eightfold path. I prefer to understand “bridge” as a metaphor for access, that is, the Buddhas no longer have the possibility of doing what is unbeneficial.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.2.17.pli: Dvīhākārehi buddhā bhagavanto bhikkhū paṭipucchanti—“dhammaṃ vā desessāma, sāvakānaṃ vā sikkhāpadaṃ paññapessāmā”ti.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.2.17.eng: Buddhas question the monks for two reasons: to give a teaching or to lay down a training rule.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.2.18.pli: Atha kho bhagavā vaggumudātīriye bhikkhū etadavoca—“yathā kathaṃ pana tumhe, bhikkhave, samaggā sammodamānā avivadamānā phāsukaṃ vassaṃ vasittha, na ca piṇḍakena kilamitthā”ti?
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.2.18.eng: And the Buddha said to those monks, “In what way, monks, did you have a comfortable and harmonious rains? And how did you get almsfood without trouble?”

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.2.19.pli: Atha kho te bhikkhū bhagavato etamatthaṃ ārocesuṃ.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.2.20.eng: “But did you really have those superhuman qualities?”

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.2.23.pli: kathañhi nāma tumhe, bhikkhave, udarassa kāraṇā gihīnaṃ aññamaññassa uttarimanussadhammassa vaṇṇaṃ bhāsissatha.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.2.23.eng: “How could you for the sake of your stomachs talk up one another’s superhuman qualities to householders?

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.2.25.pli: evañca pana, bhikkhave, imaṃ sikkhāpadaṃ uddiseyyātha—
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.2.25.eng: “And, monks, this training rule should be recited like this:

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.2.26.1.pli: “Yo pana bhikkhu anupasampannassa uttarimanussadhammaṃ āroceyya bhūtasmiṃ, pācittiyan”ti.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.2.26.1.eng: ‘If a monk truthfully tells a person who is not fully ordained of a superhuman quality, he commits an offense entailing confession.’”

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:2.1.4.eng: … The monk who has been given the full ordination by a unanimous Sangha through a legal procedure consisting of one motion and three announcements that is irreversible and fit to stand—this sort of monk is meant in this case.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:2.1.5.eng: A person who is not fully ordained:

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:2.1.6.pli: bhikkhuñca bhikkhuniñca ṭhapetvā, avaseso anupasampanno nāma.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:2.1.6.eng: anyone except a fully ordained monk or a fully ordained nun.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:2.1.8.pli: jhānaṃ, vimokkho, samādhi, samāpatti, ñāṇadassanaṃ, maggabhāvanā, phalasacchikiriyā, kilesappahānaṃ, vinīvaraṇatā cittassa, suññāgāre abhirati.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:2.1.8.eng: absorption, release, stillness, attainment, knowledge and vision, development of the path, realization of the fruits, abandoning the defilements, a mind without hindrances, delighting in solitude.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:2.1.8.comm: “Delighting in solitude” renders suññāgāra, literally, “delighting in an empty dwelling”. According to the commentaries, this is often an idiom for solitude. AN-a 1.88: Tattha ca rukkhamūlānīti iminā rukkhamūlasenāsanaṁ dasseti. Suññāgārānīti iminā janavivittaṭṭhānaṁ; “And there rukkhamūlāni: by this is shown dwellings at the foot of a tree; suññāgārāni: by this (is shown) a place free from people.”

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:2.1.10.pli: paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ, dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ, tatiyaṃ jhānaṃ, catutthaṃ jhānaṃ.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:2.1.10.eng: the first absorption, the second absorption, the third absorption, the fourth absorption.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:2.1.12.pli: suññato vimokkho, animitto vimokkho, appaṇihito vimokkho.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:2.1.12.eng: emptiness release, signless release, desireless release.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:2.1.14.pli: suññato samādhi, animitto samādhi, appaṇihito samādhi.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:2.1.14.eng: emptiness stillness, signless stillness, desireless stillness.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:2.1.16.pli: suññatā samāpatti, animittā samāpatti, appaṇihitā samāpatti.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:2.1.16.eng: emptiness attainment, signless attainment, desireless attainment.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:2.1.20.pli: cattāro satipaṭṭhānā, cattāro sammappadhānā, cattāro iddhipādā, pañcindriyāni, pañca balāni, satta bojjhaṅgā, ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:2.1.20.eng: the four applications of mindfulness, the four right efforts, the four foundations for supernormal power, the five spiritual faculties, the five spiritual powers, the seven factors of awakening, the noble eightfold path.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:2.1.22.pli: sotāpattiphalassa sacchikiriyā, sakadāgāmiphalassa sacchikiriyā, anāgāmiphalassa sacchikiriyā, arahattassa sacchikiriyā.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:2.1.22.eng: realization of the fruit of stream-entry, realization of the fruit of once-returning, realization of the fruit of non-returning, realization of perfection.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:2.1.24.pli: rāgassa pahānaṃ, dosassa pahānaṃ, mohassa pahānaṃ.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:2.1.24.eng: the abandoning of sensual desire, the abandoning of ill will, the abandoning of confusion.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:2.1.26.pli: rāgā cittaṃ vinīvaraṇatā, dosā cittaṃ vinīvaraṇatā, mohā cittaṃ vinīvaraṇatā.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:2.1.26.eng: a mind without sensual desire, a mind without ill will, a mind without confusion.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:2.1.28.pli: paṭhamena jhānena suññāgāre abhirati, dutiyena jhānena suññāgāre abhirati, tatiyena jhānena suññāgāre abhirati, catutthena jhānena suññāgāre abhirati.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:2.1.28.eng: because of the first absorption there is delight in solitude, because of the second absorption there is delight in solitude, because of the third absorption there is delight in solitude, because of the fourth absorption there is delight in solitude.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:2.2.2.pli: anupasampannassa—“paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ samāpajjin”ti bhaṇantassa āpatti pācittiyassa.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:2.2.2.eng: if a monk says to a person who is not fully ordained, “I attained the first absorption,” he commits an offense entailing confession.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:2.2.4.pli: anupasampannassa—“paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ samāpajjāmī”ti bhaṇantassa āpatti pācittiyassa.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:2.2.4.eng: if a monk says to a person who is not fully ordained, “I’m attaining the first absorption,” he commits an offense entailing confession.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:2.2.6.pli: anupasampannassa—“paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ samāpanno”ti bhaṇantassa āpatti pācittiyassa.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:2.2.6.eng: if a monk says to a person who is not fully ordained, “I’ve attained the first absorption,” he commits an offense entailing confession.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:2.2.8.pli: anupasampannassa—“paṭhamassa jhānassa lābhimhī”ti bhaṇantassa āpatti pācittiyassa.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:2.2.8.eng: if a monk says to a person who is not fully ordained, “I obtain the first absorption,” he commits an offense entailing confession.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:2.2.10.pli: anupasampannassa—“paṭhamassa jhānassa vasimhī”ti bhaṇantassa āpatti pācittiyassa.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:2.2.10.eng: if a monk says to a person who is not fully ordained, “I master the first absorption,” he commits an offense entailing confession.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:2.2.12.pli: anupasampannassa—“paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ sacchikataṃ mayā”ti bhaṇantassa āpatti pācittiyassa.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:2.2.12.eng: if a monk says to a person who is not fully ordained, “I’ve realized the first absorption,” he commits an offense entailing confession.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:2.2.14.eng: if a monk says to a person who is not fully ordained, “I attained the second absorption …

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:2.2.16.pli: catutthaṃ jhānaṃ samāpajjiṃ, samāpajjāmi, samāpanno; catutthassa jhānassa lābhimhi, vasimhi; catutthaṃ jhānaṃ sacchikataṃ mayā”ti bhaṇantassa āpatti pācittiyassa.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:2.2.16.eng: the fourth absorption … I’m attaining … I’ve attained … I obtain … I master … I’ve realized the fourth absorption,” he commits an offense entailing confession.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:2.2.18.eng: if a monk says to a person who is not fully ordained, “I attained the emptiness release …

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:2.2.23.pli: appaṇihitaṃ samādhiṃ samāpajjiṃ, samāpajjāmi, samāpanno; appaṇihitassa samādhissa lābhimhi, vasimhi; appaṇihito samādhi sacchikato mayā”ti bhaṇantassa āpatti pācittiyassa.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:2.2.23.eng: the desireless stillness … I’m attaining … I’ve attained … I obtain … I master … I’ve realized the desireless stillness,” he commits an offense entailing confession.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:2.2.25.eng: if a monk says to a person who is not fully ordained, “I attained the emptiness attainment …

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:2.4.0.eng: Meaning to say one thing, but saying something else

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:2.4.2.pli: anupasampannassa— “paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ samāpajjin”ti vattukāmo—“dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ samāpajjin”ti bhaṇantassa paṭivijānantassa āpatti pācittiyassa, na paṭivijānantassa āpatti dukkaṭassa.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:2.4.2.eng: if a monk means to say to a person who is not fully ordained, “I attained the first absorption,” but actually says, “I attained the second absorption,” then, if the listener understands, he commits an offense entailing confession; if the listener does not understand, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:2.4.2.comm: “If the listener understands” renders paṭivijānantassa. This is in accordance with Sp 1.219, which has this to say: Atha pana yassa āroceti, so na jānāti “ki ayaṁ bhaṇatī”ti, saṁsayaṁ vā āpajjati, ciraṁ vīmaṁsitvā vā pacchā jānāti, appaṭivijānanto icceva saṅkhyaṁ gacchati, “When he who is informed does not understand, thinking, ‘What does he say?’ or he has doubt, or he understands after reflecting for a long time, then it is considered ‘one who does not understand.’” Grammatically paṭivijānantassa could refer to either the speaker or the listener (it can be regarded as a genitive agreeing with bhaṇantassa, thus referring to the speaker, or it can be regarded as a dative of the person spoken to, that is, the listener), but logically it seems it must refer to the listener. In accordance with common usage, “understanding” (paṭivijānantassa) must refer to understanding the overall meaning of what is said, not to knowing the exact words that have been spoken. Since the rule requires that the speaker knows he is making a claim, he understands the overall meaning. It follows that the understanding here must refer to the listener. A parallel construction is found at Bu Pj 1:8.4.10 where paṭivijānāti is used in connection with giving up the monastic training. Here the verb clearly refers to understanding on the part of the listener, that is, one has only succeeded in renouncing the training if the listener understands what one is saying. At Bu Ss 3:4.1.4 the same verb, this time in the aorist form paṭivijāni, again refers to the listener.
